title: U.S. stock futures higher with Microsoft, GM rising after results; European gas prices in focus as Russia cuts supply to Poland, Bulgaria
text:
* S&P 500 futures ES00 rose 0.4% to 4,187.

* Dow Jones Industrial Average futures YM00 gained 219 points, or 0.7%, to 33,379.

* Nasdaq-100 futures NQ00 climbed 29 points, or 0.2%, to 13,045.

On Tuesday, the Dow industrials DJIA tumbled more than 800 points, or 2.4%. The S&P 500 SPX fell 2.8%, while the Nasdaq Composite COMP slid 4%, booking its largest daily percentage drop since Sept. 8, 2020 and its lowest close since Dec. 14, 2020, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

What's driving markets?

Investors are juggling several concerns at once, including fears the Federal Reserve could knock the economy into recession as it raises interest rates to battle high inflation, along with worries about China's COVID outbreak which is slowing economic growth, an ongoing war in Ukraine, and a mixed U.S. corporate earnings reporting season.

Microsoft MSFT shares rose 5% in premarket trading after the tech giant late Tuesday reported profit and sales estimates that beat forecasts.

But Google parent Alphabet GOOGL reported sales and earnings that came in short of estimates, and shares fell 4% in premarket trading.

Another big decliner early Wednesday was Boeing BA , with shares of the aerospace and defence giant dropping toward a 17-month lowafter much wider-than-expected loss, big revenue miss

Read: If Elon Musk and Twitter don't complete their deal, one of them will have to pay $1 billion

"Either way, tech and high beta areas of the equity market need to find some inspiration, or a further liquidation can't be ruled out â€“ at the moment it feels like catching a falling knife," said Chris Weston, head of research at Pepperstone, in a note to clients."

"Again, we ask what will [be] the circuit breaker to promote a lasting trend higher. My own view is it either comes from a belief that China has COVID under control or we hear a Fed member saying 'inflation is a concern but we're watching for signs that growth concerns or financial conditions overtighten,'" said Weston. Investors won't hear from Federal Reserve officials after the next Fed meeting on May 4.

Facebook parent Meta FB will be the next big tech company to report, with those results expected after the market close Wednesday, alongside Qualcomm QCOM, PayPal PYPL and Ford Motor F.

The U.S. trade deficit in goods jumped17.8% in March to a record $125.3 billion, government data showed. A home-price index is due later Wednesday morning.

Investors are also keeping watch on tensions surrounding the war in Ukraine, with signs of escalation after Russia's Gazprom said Wednesday that it is halting gas deliveries to Bulgaria and Poland due to a failure by those countries to pay in rubles. European gas prices saw a 10% jump.

"It further highlights the vulnerability of other EU-members like Germany as they risk similar cutoffs soon," said strategists at Danske Bank, in a note to clients. Those tensions weighed on the euro EURUSD, which fell 0.3% against the dollar and to its weakest level since April 2017.

Crude prices CL00 BRN00 gave up early gains to turn lower.

Read: 'Energy is being increasingly weaponized.' Analysts weigh up risks after Russia cuts gas to two EU countries

What companies are in focus?

* General Motors Co. GM shares rose 2% in premarket trading after the automaker reported disappointing first-quarter revenue, but gave upbeat guidance.

* Stock in Texas Instruments Inc. TXN fell 3% after the chip maker gave a cautious outlook over COVID-19 restrictions in China affecting manufacturing for its customers.

* Robinhood Markets Inc. HOOD fell 4.5%. The online-trading platform's chief executive, Vlad Tenev, announced a 9% cut in the company's work force.

* Mattel Inc. MAT shares surged 10% after The Wall Street Journal reported the toy maker has held informal talks with private-equity firms Apollo Global Management and L Catterton about being purchased.

How are other assets trading?

* The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y fell 3.2 basis points to 2.741%. Yields and debt prices move opposite each other.

* The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, was up 0.5%.

* Bitcoin BTCUSD was down 5.3% at around $39,031.

* Gold for June delivery GC00 GCM22 was flat after dipping below $1,900 an ounce.

* In European equities, the Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP and London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX gained 0.6%.

* In Asia, the Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP rose 2.4%, while the Hang Seng Index HSI, +0.06% finished flat in Hong Kong and Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIKfell 1.1%.

U.S. stock futures higher with Microsoft, GM rising after results
